I kindly ask the CFPB to require the involved parties to correct, delete, or update the disputed information on my credit report in line with the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), so that my credit report can reflect my accurate financial history. I am attaching supporting documents and I look forward to your assistance in resolving this matter promptly. Thank you for your attention to this request.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am submitting this formal complaint to the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ) against Experian for failing to adequately address and correct an inaccurate late payment mark on my credit report : account : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX The circumstances surrounding this delay were entirely beyond my control and were caused by procedural failures on the part of the creditor. Despite disputing this late payment with Experian and providing substantial evidence to support my claim, the bureau has failed to properly investigate and correct this inaccurate reporting. 
Erroneous Late Payment Reporting : The late payment mark reported on my credit file stems from the following situation : Prior to the payment due date, my account experienced a fraudulent transaction, which I promptly disputed with XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX. 
The unresolved dispute led to a block on my account, preventing me from accessing it to make a timely payment. 
The payment was made on XX/XX/year>, immediately after XXXX XXXX resolved the issue. 
The delay in payment was entirely caused by XXXX XXXX failure to act promptly to address the fraudulent transaction and unblock my account. This late payment does not reflect my financial responsibility or payment behavior. 
Experians Failure to Investigate : Despite submitting a formal dispute to Experian with clear evidence demonstrating the inaccuracy of this late payment mark, Experian has failed to properly investigate and correct the information as required under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ). Instead, the inaccurate late payment remains on my credit report, causing significant damage to my credit score and financial standing. 
Harm to My Financial Standing : This inaccurate late payment mark has caused unnecessary harm to my credit score, jeopardizing my ability to secure financing for my business. It is unjust for this negative mark to persist on my report due to failures by both XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX and Experian to fulfill their legal obligations. 
Legal Violations by Experian Failure to Conduct a Reasonable Investigation ( FCRA, Section 1681i ) : Experian is required to conduct a reasonable investigation of disputes submitted by consumers. The bureau failed to thoroughly investigate my claim, disregarding the evidence I provided that clearly demonstrated the inaccuracy of the late payment.

Failure to Ensure Maximum Possible Accuracy ( FCRA, Section 607 ( b ) ) : Experian has a legal obligation to ensure that all information on a consumers credit report is accurate. By failing to address this dispute, the bureau is perpetuating inaccurate information on my credit file. 
Negligence in Verifying Information Provided by the Creditor ( FCRA, Section 1681s-2 ( b ) ) : Experian is obligated to verify the accuracy of the information furnished by XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX This obligation includes ensuring that any negative marks reported are accurate and substantiated. 
By failing to correct this inaccuracy, Experian is violating my rights under the FCRA, causing undue harm to my financial reputation. 
The inaccurate late payment mark on my credit report is unjust, harmful, and violates my rights under the FCRA. I urge the CFPB to investigate Experians handling of my dispute and ensure that this matter is resolved promptly and fairly. 
Thank you for your attention to this matter. I look forward to a resolution that reflects the fairness and accuracy required by law.
Company public response: Company has responded to the consumer and the CFPB and chooses not to provide a public response

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Issue: Problem with a company's investigation into an existing problem
Sub-issue: Their investigation did not fix an error on your report
Consumer complaint narrative:
XXXX XXXX XXXX Experian for Non-Compliance with FCRA 605B and Failure to Address Fraudulent Items in My Credit Report To Whom It May Concern, I am filing this complaint due to Experian 's willful non-compliance with the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), specifically under 605B, in relation to fraudulent items on my credit report that I have disputed. Experian has failed to remove these items despite being provided with comprehensive documentation, which includes my identity theft report, proof of address, government-issued identification, and additional documentation linking me to a data breach incident.

Summary of Noncompliance and Violations : I first submitted a dispute to Experian, along with all required documentation, citing my rights under 605B of the FCRA, which clearly mandates that credit reporting agencies must block any information that resulted from identity theft within XXXX XXXX XXXX  upon receipt of such notification. Experian 's failure to act not only violates 605B but also disregards the legislative intent behind the FCRA, which is designed to protect consumers from the severe consequences of fraudulent reporting and identity theft. 

Experian 's failure to act appears to be in direct contravention of the court 's stance in XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, where it was established that credit reporting agencies bear significant responsibility in ensuring accuracy and must adequately address disputes involving identity theft. By refusing to block these fraudulent entries on my report, Experian is knowingly and willfully neglecting this duty. Furthermore, in XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX the court underscored the consumer 's right to a fair investigation by credit reporting agencies. In failing to fulfill their legal obligations, Experian has also demonstrated non-compliance with the CFPB 's XXXX bulletin on credit reporting agencies ' responsibilities in the handling of identity theft complaints. 

Attached you will find proof of my previous attempts to dispute the fraudulent accounts on my consumer report with Experian, proof that I was a victim of the XXXX XXXX XXXX, Proof of ID, SSN, Proof of address, and the FTC Affidavit listing the fraudulent Kikoff Account.

I demand the late payment to be updated.

They are not in compliance with the following law. 15 USC 1666b and its requirements set the standards and the guidance for a creditor to treat a payment as late, yet they are reporting a payment as late and they did not comply with the law!

15 USC 1666b ( a ) Time to make payments A creditor may not treat a payment on a credit card account under an open end consumer credit plan as late for any purpose, unless the creditor has adopted reasonable procedures designed to ensure that each periodic statement including the information required by section 1637 ( b ) of this title is mailed or delivered to the consumer not later than 21 days before the payment due date.

Never Sent the periodic statement along with the disclosures from section 1637 ( b ).

I have requested proof that this information was mailed or delivered 21 days before the payment due date and this information was requested in good faith pursuant rule 1002 and It was never provided. 


This is unfair, illegal, fraudulent, and not equitable to me as a consumer!

Product: Debt collection
Sub-issue: Didn't receive notice of right to dispute
Consumer complaint narrative:
I checked my credit and it said I had a collection never received a letter never received anything instantly went on my credit. First of all, they value my hippa rights .Second, my hippa right to privacy. All three of the credit bureaus should have XXXX due diligence under 15 U.S. Code 1681 - Congressional findings and statement of purpose 3 ) Consumer reporting agencies have assumed a vital role in assembling and evaluating consumer credit and other information on consumers.15 U.S. Code 1692e - False or misleading representations U.S. Code Notes prev | next A debt collector may not use any false, deceptive, or misleading representation or means in connection with the collection of any debt. Without limiting the general application of the foregoing, the following conduct is a violation of this section : ( 1 ) The false representation or implication that the debt collector is vouched for, bonded by, or affiliated with the United States or any State, including the use of any badge, uniform, or facsimile thereof.

( 2 ) The false representation of ( A ) the character, amount, or legal status of any debt; or ( B ) any services rendered or compensation which may be lawfully received by any debt collector for the collection of a debt.

( 3 ) The false representation or implication that any individual is an attorney or that any communication is from an attorney.

( 4 ) The representation or implication that nonpayment of any debt will result in the arrest or imprisonment of any person or the seizure, garnishment, attachment, or sale of any property or wages of any person unless such action is lawful and the debt collector or creditor intends to take such action.

( 5 ) The threat to take any action that can not legally be taken or that is not intended to be taken.

( 6 ) The false representation or implication that a sale, referral, or other transfer of any interest in a debt shall cause the consumer to ( A ) lose any claim or defense to payment of the debt; or ( B ) become subject to any practice prohibited by this subchapter.

( 7 ) The false representation or implication that the consumer committed any crime or other conduct in order to disgrace the consumer.

( 8 ) Communicating or threatening to communicate to any person credit information which is known or which should be known to be false, including the failure to communicate that a disputed debt is disputed.

( 9 ) The use or distribution of any written communication which simulates or is falsely represented to be a document authorized, issued, or approved by any court, official, or agency of the United States or any State, or which creates a false impression as to its source, authorization, or approval.

( 10 ) The use of any false representation or deceptive means to collect or attempt to collect any debt or to obtain information concerning a consumer.

Subject : Discrepancy Regarding Account Status and Request for Clarification Dear XXXX XXXX, I am writing to formally address a discrepancy I have identified regarding my account with XXXX XXXX. Specifically, the status of this account is being inaccurately reported as " charged off '' on my credit reports from Experian and XXXX. However, when I contacted XXXX XXXX directly, I was informed that this account was not charged off. 
Additionally, I have been advised by XXXX XXXX that no IRS Form 1099-C was filed for this account. Yet, I am being contacted by a collection agency and receiving phone calls regarding this matter. I find this situation confusing and concerning, as it appears to conflict with the information provided by your company. For reference, I have included copies of my credit reports and the notifications I have received from the collection agency. 
I respectfully request the following actions and clarifications : Confirmation in writing of the current status of my account with XXXX XXXX. 
A clear explanation of why my credit reports reflect a " charged off '' status if this is not accurate. 
Confirmation that no Form 1099-C was filed with the IRS, as stated by your representative. 
Correction to my credit report If there has been an error in reporting this account to Experian and XXXX, I request that you promptly correct the information with both credit bureaus and provide me with written confirmation of the correction. 
Should you require additional information to resolve this matter, please do not hesitate to contact me in me writing. 
Thank you for your immediate attention to this matter. I look forward to your response within 30 days of receiving this letter, as per the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ). 
Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX Enclosures : Notifications received from the collection agency

Product: Debt collection
Issue: Attempts to collect debt not owed
Consumer complaint narrative: All three companies are reporting inaccurate, incorrect, and invalid on my credit report to provide information that they are not legally allowed to report information to my credit report pursuant to the following statutes : 15 US Code 1681 ( 4 ) 15 US Code 1681 ( A ) 15 US Code 1681 ( E ) 15 US Code 1637 1. **Failure to Provide Validation of Debt : ** I have not received proper validation of the debt in question as required by FCRA Section 809 ( b ). Despite my previous requests for detailed documentation validating the debt, including the original signed contract and a breakdown of charges, this information has not been provided. 2. **Reporting Inaccuracies : ** The reported information appears to be inaccurate, and it is my right under FCRA Section 611 ( a ) to have a thorough investigation conducted. I am formally disputing the accuracy of this account, and I request that you promptly correct any inaccuracies and provide me with a corrected credit report. XXXX. **Failure to Respond to Dispute : ** It has come to my attention that my previous dispute, has not been adequately addressed within the statutory timeframe outlined in FCRA Section 611 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ). This failure to respond violates my rights under the FCRA. 4. **Failure to Report Dispute to Furnisher : ** I also note that, as per FCRA Section 623 ( a ) ( 8 ), the collection agency is obligated to report my dispute to the original creditor. Failure to do so is a violation of this section of the FCRA. Given these violations, I am formally requesting the immediate deletion of the disputed collection account from my credit report. Furthermore, I insist that you provide written confirmation of the account 's removal and a corrected credit report within 15 days of receiving this letter. Additionally, I am invoking my rights under the SAFE Act to request information about the original creditor, the nature of the debt, and any supporting documentation that establishes your authority to collect this debt. The SAFE Act requires debt collectors to provide consumers with specific information about the debt in question. I expect your prompt attention to this matter and appreciate your cooperation in resolving this dispute.

Product: Debt collection
Issue: Took or threatened to take negative or legal action
Sub-issue: Threatened or suggested your credit would be damaged
Consumer complaint narrative:
Subject : Request for Debt Validation Pursuant to the FDCPA Dear Ideal Collection Agency, I am writing in response to your recent communication regarding an alleged debt you claim I owe. As per my rights under the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ), 15 U.S.C. 1692g, I am requesting that you provide proper validation of this debt to ensure its validity.

Please provide the following documentation : 1. The exact amount of the alleged debt ; 2. The name and address of the original creditor ; 3. A copy of any agreement bearing my signature that demonstrates my liability for the debt ; 4. Verification of the debt or a copy of any judgment ; and 5. Proof that you, Ideal Collection XXXX, are legally authorized to collect on this debt. 



Until you provide the above documentation to verify the debt, you are legally prohibited from : Continuing collection activities, including phone calls and written communication ; Reporting the debt to any credit reporting agencies ; Initiating any legal action regarding this debt. 



Demand for Immediate Action : 1. Cease All Collection Activity : You are required to immediately halt all collection efforts, including phone calls, written communication, or credit reporting, until the requested documentation is provided.

2. Provide Debt Validation : Within 30 days, you must submit the legally required validation of this debt. Failure to do so will result in formal complaints filed with the Federal Trade Commission ( FTC ) and the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ) for violations of the FDCPA.

Failure to comply with these legal obligations may result in my pursuing legal action against Ideal Collection XXXX for attempting to collect an unverified debt, as well as damages for violations of my rights under the FDCPA. 



If this alleged debt can not be validated within the time prescribed by law, I will consider the matter closed and will request that all references to this alleged debt be removed from any credit reporting agencies. 



Thank you for your prompt attention to this matter. All future correspondence must be in writing and sent to the address listed above. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX

Issue: Problem with a company's investigation into an existing problem
Sub-issue: Their investigation did not fix an error on your report
Consumer complaint narrative:
Subject : Follow-Up Dispute of Collection Account Request for Method of Verification To Whom It XXXX Concern, I, XXXX XXXX XXXX am following up on my previous dispute regarding the collection account listed on my credit report under the account XXXX. In my initial dispute, I requested the removal of this account due to the collection agency 's failure to provide debt validation. 
Under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) 611 ( a ) ( 6 ), I am entitled to know the method used to verify the accuracy of this collection account. Specifically, I am requesting : 1. The method used to verify the accuracy of this collection account.

2. The name and contact information of the person or entity that provided the verification.

3. Copies of any documents or records used in the reinvestigation process.

As the collection agency did not provide validation, the continued presence of this account on my credit report is both inaccurate and non-compliant with the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ) 809 ( a ).

Please provide the requested information and update my credit report accordingly. If the information can not be verified, this collection account must be removed from my credit file as required by FCRA 611 ( a ) ( 5 ) ( A ).

Thank you for your prompt attention to this matter. I expect a response within the 30-day period allowed by law

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Consumer complaint narrative:
XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, NJ XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX, PA XXXX Experian XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, TX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, GA XXXX RE : XXXX : XXXX To Whom It May Concern, I am writing to formally address the unauthorized reporting of fraudulent accounts on my consumer report due to identity theft. Your failure to properly verify and correct this information is in violation of the legal requirements set forth by federal law.

Violation of 15 USC 1681b ( c ) Furnishing Reports in Connection with Unauthorized Credit or Insurance Transactions According to this statute, a consumer reporting agency is prohibited from disclosing records of inquiries related to transactions not initiated by the consumer, unless explicitly exempted by law.

Immediate Action Required : The following fraudulent inquiries, stemming from identity theft, were not initiated by me and must be removed without delay : Inquiry : Identity Theft and Federal Law Compliance Under 18 U.S.C. 1028A ( Aggravated Identity Theft ), using another person 's identifying information without lawful authority during a felony constitutes a severe offense, punishable by imprisonment. The existence of unauthorized accounts on my credit report constitutes clear evidence of identity misuse.

Permissible Purposes of Consumer Reports Under 15 USC 1681b ( a ) ( 2 ), consumer reporting agencies may only provide consumer reports with written consent from the consumer. This standard has not been met in my case.

Ensuring Fairness and Accuracy As per 15 USC 1681 ( Fair Credit Reporting Act ), consumer reporting agencies must uphold their responsibilities with fairness, impartiality, and respect for consumer privacy. 
List of Fraudulent Accounts : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX Pursuant to 15 U.S. Code 1681c2 Block of Fraudulent Information I demand that, as stipulated by law, you block the reporting of the fraudulent information in question within 4 business days of receiving this correspondence and the attached supporting documentation.

Enclosed Supporting Documents : Copy of government-issued ID Proof of address ( utility bill ) Copy of Social Security Card Official FTC Identity Theft Report Updated Report Request I request an updated copy of my corrected consumer file, as entitled under 15 USC 1681c-1 ( 2 ), which provides consumers access to free reports when fraud alerts are involved.

CC : Bureau of Consumer Financial Protection ( CFPB ) Federal Trade Commission ( FTC ) XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX Attorney Generals Office ( State of Pennsylvania and respective state of each bureau ) Thank you for your prompt attention to this matter. 
Sincerely, XXXX XXXX Enclosures : Copy of ID Utility bill Copy of Social Security Card FTC Identity Theft Report

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to formally file a complaint against Wayfair Card Services for violating my consumer rights under the Fair Credit Billing Act ( 15 U.S.C. 1666 ) and the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( 15 U.S.C. 1681 et seq. ). 

More than XXXX years ago, Wayfair Card Services canceled my account with a balance of only {$500.00}. Since then, I have made consistent payments toward the balance. However, the company continues to add exorbitant amounts of interest, making it nearly impossible to pay off the account. Despite my efforts to meet my obligations, Wayfair Card Services has also falsely reported late payments to my credit report. 

These actions are not only predatory but also violate my rights as a consumer. Specifically : Under the Fair Credit Billing Act, creditors are prohibited from applying unfair or excessive charges, particularly when a good faith effort has been made to resolve the balance. 
Under the Fair Credit Reporting Act, creditors are required to report accurate and fair information to credit reporting agencies. The late payment reports are erroneous and detrimental to my credit history. 
I kindly request that the CFPB investigate Wayfair Card Services practices and intervene to ensure compliance with federal laws. Additionally, I respectfully request that this account be removed from my credit report to prevent further financial harm, as their practices have made it unjustly impossible for me to resolve this matter. 

Thank you for your attention to this issue. Please feel free to contact me if further information or documentation is needed.

Product: Debt collection
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing in response to your recent communication, which pertains to the debt you claim I owe. After carefully reviewing your response, I must reject your statements for the following reasons : False Statements in Violation of FDCPA : Your response contains inaccurate and misleading statements that I believe to be false. These false assertions not only misrepresent the facts but also violate the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ), which prohibits the use of false, deceptive, or misleading representations in the collection of a debt. 

False Statements ( 15 USC 1692e ( 8 ) ) : Your response contains false and misleading statements in violation of 15 USC 1692e ( 8 ), which prohibits the reporting of false information to credit bureaus. Specifically, [ describe the false statement ( s ), e.g., " you inaccurately reported missed payments despite my records showing no such missed payments '' ]. As the court stated in XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX ( XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  such misrepresentations violate the FDCPA, and continued use of false information is actionable. 

Failure to Provide Original Signed Contract : In addition to the false statements, you have failed to provide an original signed contract or any document that legally substantiates your claim of debt. Under Section 809 of the FDCPA, you are required to provide verification of the debt upon my request, which includes the original contract or a copy bearing my signature to prove that I am indeed responsible for the debt in question. Your failure to produce such documentation demonstrates non-compliance with this legal requirement. 

As such, I request that you cease and desist any further collection efforts related to this matter, as it is clear that the debt you are attempting to collect is not substantiated by valid documentation. Additionally, I request that you correct any inaccuracies you have reported to the credit bureaus regarding this debt, as it is based on false information. 

Please be advised that any continued violation of the FDCPA will be reported to the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ), the Federal Trade Commission ( FTC ), and any relevant state authorities. 

I expect to receive written confirmation of your compliance with these requests within 30 days. If you continue to pursue this matter without proper evidence and in violation of the FDCPA, I will take further action to protect my rights.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Credit inquiries on your report that you don't recognize
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to formally lodge a complaint regarding the actions taken by the staff at XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX in XXXX, LA, on XX/XX/year>, during my visit to purchase a new vehicle. 

I arrived at the dealership with a pre-approval for financing through XXXX XXXX XXXX, a financial institution with which I have been a long-time customer. Before my visit, I clearly communicated to the sales team that I had already secured financing through XXXX XXXX and requested that they match my pre-approval with only one inquiry via XXXX XXXX, as per standard procedure. 

However, despite my explicit instructions, the sales manager proceeded to run a total of four credit inquiriesone authorized through XXXX XXXX and three unauthorized inquiries through XXXX XXXX 's in-house financing, XXXX XXXX XXXX and Ally Financing. I immediately received alerts from my credit monitoring service regarding these inquiries. In response, I rushed to the finance office and urgently requested that they stop, as these additional inquiries would harm my credit score. The response I received was dismissive, with the finance staff assuring me that " when you buy a car, these will fall off. '' I knew at that moment that this statement was false. 

Since that time, I have made repeated attempts to contact the finance manager, leaving multiple messages, and have also reached out to the respective finance companies involved. Unfortunately, none of these efforts have resulted in any resolution or assistance. 

I would like to state, with my mother as a witness to the events, that none of these unauthorized inquiries were permitted by me. Despite this, the dealership has refused to acknowledge or rectify the situation, which I believe constitutes a serious case of fraud. 

I am requesting immediate assistance and resolution regarding this matter, as these unauthorized credit inquiries have negatively impacted my credit score and caused undue distress.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am filing a complaint against [ Name of Credit Bureau, such as EXPERIAN and the associated information furnisher for inaccurately reporting late payments on my XXXX XXXX XXXX account with account number XXXX. 
This incorrect information in my credit report violates several regulations, including the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), the Truth in Lending Act ( TILA ), the Protection Against Non-Payment of Obligations Act ( PAANL ), and Unfair, Deceptive, or Abusive Acts or Practices ( UDAAP ).

1. FCRA : The credit bureau and the information furnisher have failed to ensure the accuracy of the data in my report, and the incorrect information continues to appear despite my request for a manual and thorough verification, as required by the FCRA. The lack of manual investigation, as well as possible reliance on the automated XXXX system, constitutes a violation of 15 U.S.C. 1681i and 1681s-2.

2. TILA : I have not received periodic billing statements within the legal timeframe of 21 days before the payment due date, which has resulted in the incorrect reporting of late payments. I request the provision of records demonstrating compliance with TILA requirements, specifically 15 U.S.C. 1637 ( b ) and 12 CFR 1026.5.

3. UDAAP : The inaccurate information regarding my late payments affects my credit score and may mislead potential creditors. I believe this constitutes a deceptive practice under UDAAP regulations overseen by the CFPB.

Subject : Dispute of XXXX XXXX XXXX Collection Account Under FCRA To Whom It XXXX Concern, I am writing to dispute the collection account reported by XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX on my Equifax credit report. Based on my investigation through the XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX is not licensed to collect debts in the state of California. Under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), specifically XXXX XXXX XXXX ( b ), Equifax is required to ensure the maximum possible accuracy of the information contained in consumer reports. Reporting a collection account from an unlicensed entity that is prohibited from collecting debts in California fails to meet this standard. Furthermore, under XXXX XXXX XXXX ( a ) ( XXXX ), I have the right to dispute inaccurate or unverifiable information, which obligates Equifax to investigate and remove such information from my credit report if it can not be verified.

Provide Written Confirmation : Send me a written response confirming the removal of this account and provide an updated copy of my credit report reflecting the correction. 

Equifax must complete this investigation and respond within the XXXX timeframe required under the FCRA. Failure to comply with these obligations will leave me no choice but to escalate this matter by filing complaints with the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ), the Federal Trade Commission ( FTC ), and the California Attorney Generals office.

Privacy of Consumer Financial Information ; 16 CFR 313.1 Purpose and Scope ; 16 CFR 313.7 Forms of Opt-Out Notice to Consumers ; Opt-out methods; 16 CFR 433.2 Preservation of consumers ' claims and defenses, unfair or deceptive acts or practices.

16 CFR 433.3 Exemption of sellers taking or receiving open-end consumer credit contracts before XX/XX/XXXX from requirements of 433.2 ( a ).

16 CFR 444.2 Unfair credit practices.

15 U.S. Code 1681- Congressional findings and statement of purpose : ( a ) Accuracy and fairness of credit reporting The Congress makes the following findings : ( 1 ) The banking system is dependent upon fair and accurate credit reporting. Inaccurate credit reports directly impair the efficiency of the banking system, and unfair credit reporting methods undermine the public confidence which is essential to the continued functioning of the banking system. ( 2 ) An elaborate mechanism has been developed for investigating and evaluating the credit worthiness, credit standing, credit capacity, character, and general reputation of consumers. ( 3 ) Consumer reporting agencies have assumed a vital role in assembling and evaluating consumer credit and other information on consumers. ( 4 ) There is a need to insure that consumer reporting agencies exercise their grave responsibilities with fairness, impartiality, and a respect for the consumers right to privacy.

( b ) Reasonable procedures It is the purpose of this subchapter to require that consumer reporting agencies adopt reasonable procedures for meeting the needs of commerce for consumer credit, personnel, insurance, and other information in a manner which is fair and equitable to the consumer, with regard to the confidentiality, accuracy, relevancy, and proper utilization of such information in accordance with the requirements of this subchapter.

15 U.S. Code 1681b - Permissible purposes of consumer : ( A ). intends to use the information in connection with a credit transaction involving the consumer on whom the information is to be furnished.

15 U.S. Code 6801 - Protection of nonpublic personal information : ( a ) Privacy obligation policy It is the policy of the Congress that each financial institution has an affirmative and continuing obligation to respect the privacy of its customers and to protect the security and confidentiality of those customers nonpublic personal information. ( b ) Financial institutions safeguards In furtherance of the policy in subsection ( a ), each agency or authority described in section 6805 ( a ) of this title, other than the Bureau of Consumer Financial Protection, shall establish appropriate standards for the financial institutions subject to their jurisdiction relating to administrative, technical, and physical safeguards ( 1 ) to insure the security and confidentiality of customer records and information ; ( 2 ) to protect against any anticipated threats or hazards to the security or integrity of such records ; and ( 3 ) to protect against unauthorized access to or use of such records or information which could result in substantial harm or inconvenience to any customer.

A 3rd Party debt collector means there was a charge-off ; a charge-off is a certificate of indebtedness, this is income and must be removed from my credit reports.

The Privacy Act of 1974, as amended, 5 U.S.C. 552a, establishes a code of fair information practices that governs the collection, maintenance, use, and dissemination of information about individuals that is maintained in systems of records by federal agencies. A system of records is a group of records under the control of an agency from which information is retrieved by the name of the individual or by some identifier assigned to the individual.

Product: Mortgage
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to lodge a formal complaint against United Wholesale Mortgage ( UWM ), an escrow service provider, for serious mismanagement of my escrow account and mortgage payments, leading to substantial financial harm and the risk of losing my home. Despite multiple attempts to resolve these issues directly with UWM, their persistent negligence and failure to adhere to explicit instructions necessitate regulatory intervention. 

In XXXX, due to financial hardships exacerbated by the pandemic, I enrolled in a tax relief program to manage my property tax payments. Despite informing UWM of this arrangement and explicitly instructing them not to make tax payments from my escrow, UWM disregarded this directive, leading to unnecessary withdrawals for taxes, late fees, and penalties. It took extensive communication and the threat of reporting their actions before UWM partially refunded the overpayments. 

In the subsequent year, amid ongoing financial difficulties, I was accepted into a mortgage relief program. I provided UWM with all requisite documentation and repeatedly confirmed, including through multiple phone calls, that my mortgage payments should not be made through the escrow during this relief period. Contrary to these explicit instructions and documented agreements, UWM made unauthorized payments, jeopardizing my financial stability and placing my home at imminent risk of foreclosure. 

Furthermore, the mortgage relief program disbursed over {$32000.00} to bring my account current and assist with my hardship, yet UWM failed to apply these funds as intended. Despite assurances that my account was current, I later received notifications of delinquency without clarity on the application of the over {$32000.00}. My requests for a thorough investigation and account review have been met with indifference, with each interaction marred by a lack of continuity and accountability from UWM 's representatives. 

This pattern of behavior by UWM demonstrates a blatant disregard for consumer rights and financial regulations, warranting a comprehensive review by your agency. The financial and emotional toll of UWM 's actions, coupled with the looming threat of foreclosure, underscores the urgency of this matter. 

I request your agency 's immediate intervention to investigate these grievances, ensure UWM 's compliance with applicable financial regulations, and mandate appropriate corrective actions to remedy the harm caused. Enclosed are copies of all relevant communications, documents, and evidence supporting my complaint. 

Thank you for your attention to this critical matter. I am willing to provide further information as needed and look forward to your prompt response. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative: XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XX/XX/2023 I'm writing to say that the law, called the Fair Credit Reporting Act, protects my privacy. It says that companies like XXXX and XXXX, which share people 's financial information, must be fair and respect my privacy. Another law, 15 USC 6801, says that financial institutions, like the ones sharing my information, have to protect my privacy. I don't want them to share my information, and they need my permission to do so. Even if they had my permission before, I'm taking it back now. 15 USC 6802 says that a financial institution can't share my private information unless they explain how I can say no. They never told me I could say no. Moreover, another law, 15 USC 1681C, says that they can't share negative information about me without my permission. But they're doing it anyway, which is against the law. There are more laws, like 15 U.S. Code 1681s2 and 15 U.S. Code 1681e, that say companies like XXXX and XXXX must be careful and accurate when sharing information. But it seems like they're not following those rules. One more thing, according to 12 CFR 1016.7, I can choose not to let them share my information at any time. So, I'm choosing not to let them do it anymore. Thank you for understanding. Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX

So I then asked them to provide me a description of the investigation according to 15 USC 1681 ( 7 ) : ( 7 ) Description of reinvestigation procedure A consumer reporting agency shall provide to a consumer a description referred to in paragraph ( 6 ) ( B ) ( iii ) by not later than 15 days after receiving a request from the consumer for that description. 
But they did not do that as well either. 

They are also breaking these laws as well below : According to 15 USC 1681 ( 5 ) it states this ( 5 ) Treatment of inaccurate or unverifiable information ( A ) In general If, after any reinvestigation under paragraph ( 1 ) of any information disputed by a consumer, an item of the information is found to be inaccurate or incomplete or can not be verified, the consumer reporting agency shall ( i ) promptly delete that item of information from the file of the consumer, or modify that item of information, as appropriate, based on the results of the reinvestigation; and ( ) promptly notify the furnisher of that information that the information has been modified or deleted from the file of the consumer. 
According to 15 USC 1681s-2 it states this. ( A ) Reporting information with actual knowledge of errors A person shall not furnish any information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if the person knows or has reasonable cause to believe that the information is inaccurate. 
( B ) Reporting information after notice and confirmation of errors A person shall not furnish information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if ( i ) the person has been notified by the consumer, at the address specified by the person for such notices, that specific information is inaccurate; and ( i ) the information is, in fact, inaccurate.

Despite multiple requests for correction, including dispute letters sent on XX/XX/year> and XX/XX/year>, the erroneous late payment information has not been corrected. This ongoing inaccuracy violates provisions of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), the Truth in Lending Act ( TILA ), and the Protection Against Non-Payment of Obligations Act ( PAANL ). 
Discrepancies : Last Verified : Only TransUnion has a last verified date ( XX/XX/year> ) ; XXXX and XXXX do not list one.

Two-Year Payment History : TransUnion : XXXX late payment reported for XX/XX/year>. 
XXXX : XXXX late payment reported for XX/XX/year>. 
XXXX : XXXX late payment reported for XX/XX/year>. 
Violations : Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) : Under 15 U.S.C. 1681i, credit reporting agencies are required to ensure the accuracy of the information they report. The continued presence of inaccurate late payment entries on my credit report demonstrates non-compliance with this mandate. 
Truth in Lending Act ( TILA ) : According to 15 U.S.C. 1666b, creditors must provide periodic statements at least 21 days before the payment due date. The inaccurate reporting of late payments suggests a failure to comply with this requirement.

Protection Against Non-Payment of Obligations Act ( PAANL ) : Creditors are obligated to ensure timely and accurate statements to avoid unfair penalties to consumers. The erroneous late payment information violates this responsibility. 
Evidence of Error : Payment History : Documentation from XXXX XXXX confirms no late payments were made on this account for the periods in question. 
Prior Disputes : Attached copies of my previous dispute letters dated XX/XX/year> and XX/XX/year>, along with proof of submission. 
Account Statements : Monthly statements from XXXX XXXX confirming on-time payments for XXXX and XX/XX/year>. 
Discrepancies : Last Verified : Only TransUnion has a last verified date ( XX/XX/year> ) ; XXXX and XXXX do not list one. 
Date of Last Activity : Only TransUnion lists a date ( XX/XX/year> ) ; XXXX and XXXX do not list one. 
Date Reported : All bureaus list differing dates ( TransUnion : XX/XX/year> ; XXXX : XX/XX/year> ; XXXX : XX/XX/year> ). 
Closed Date : Only TransUnion lists a closed date ( XX/XX/year> ) ; XXXX and XXXX do not. 
Account Rating : All bureaus list the account as closed, but only TransUnion provides a specific closed date. 
Desired Resolution : Immediate removal of all inaccurate late payment notations from my credit report across TransUnion, XXXX, and XXXX. 
Written confirmation of the corrections made to my credit file. 
Failure to resolve this issue promptly will result in further escalation, including additional complaints and potential legal action. 
Thank you for your attention to this matter. 
Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX

Publication 4681, Canceled Debts, Foreclosures, Repossessions, and Abandonments ( For Individuals ) : This publication explains the federal tax treatment of canceled debts, foreclosures, repossessions, and abandonments. Generally, if you owe a debt to someone else and they cancel or forgive that debt for less than its full amount, you are treated for income tax purposes as having income and may have to pay tax on this income. Note. This publication generally refers to debt that is canceled, forgiven, or discharged for less than the full amount of the debt as canceled debt. ( PRIVACY ACT OF 1974 ) IT IS ILLEGAL TO REPORT TRANSACTION HISTORY. ALL ADDRESSES ON MY CREDIT REPORT ARE NON MAILABLE. EXCEPT FOR THE MOST RECENT ONE. I BELIEVE MY RIGHTS UNDER FERPA, SPECIFICALLY REGARDING THE PRIVACY OF MY STUDENT LOAN INFORMATION, HAVE BEEN VIOLATED. THE DISCLOSURE OF MY STUDENT LOAN RECORDS TO CREDIT BUREAUS WITHOUT MY CONSENT IS CONCERNING AND APPEARS TO CONTRADICT FERPA REGULATIONS. 20 U.S. Code 1232g - Family educational and privacy rights 34 CFR Part 99 - PART 99FAMILY EDUCATIONAL RIGHTS AND PRIVACY The Privacy Act of 1974, 5 U.S.C. 552a, as amended, allows individuals to gain access to their own personal records subject to certain exemptions, and to seek correction or amendment of records maintained by Federal agencies that are inaccurate, incomplete, untimely, or irrelevant. I WOULD ALSO LIKE TO OPT OUT OF ALL WHO ARE REPORTING MY INFORMATION ACCORDING TO 16 CFR 313.7. 16 CFR 433.2 Preservation of consumers ' claims and defenses, unfair or deceptive acts or practices. NOTICE ANY HOLDER OF THIS CONSUMER CREDIT CONTRACT IS SUBJECT TO ALL CLAIMS AND DEFENSES WHICH THE DEBTOR COULD ASSERT AGAINST THE SELLER OF GOODS OR SERVICES OBTAINED PURSUANT HERETO OR WITH THE PROCEEDS HEREOF. RECOVERY HEREUNDER BY THE DEBTOR SHALL NOT EXCEED AMOUNTS PAID BY THE DEBTOR HEREUNDER. 16 CFR 433.3 Exemption of sellers taking or receiving open end consumer credit contracts before XX/XX/XXXX from requirements of 433.2 ( a ). 15 U.S. Code 6805 - Enforcement ( a ) In general Subject to subtitle B of the Consumer Financial Protection Act of 2010 [ 12 U.S.C. 5511 et seq. ], this subchapter and the regulations prescribed thereunder shall be enforced by the Bureau of Consumer Financial Protection, the Federal functional regulators, the State insurance authorities, and the Federal Trade Commission with respect to financial institutions and other persons subject to their jurisdiction under applicable law, as follows : ( 1 ) Under section 1818 of title 12, by the appropriate Federal banking agency, as defined in section 1813 ( q ) of title 12, in the case of ( A ) national banks, Federal branches and Federal agencies of foreign banks, and any subsidiaries of such entities ( except brokers, dealers, persons providing insurance, investment companies, and investment advisers ) ; ( B ) member banks of the Federal Reserve System ( other than national banks ), branches and agencies of foreign banks ( other than Federal branches, Federal agencies, and insured State branches of foreign banks ), commercial lending companies owned or controlled by foreign banks, organizations operating under section 25 or 25A of the Federal Reserve Act [ 12 U.S.C. 601 et seq., 611 et seq. ], and bank holding companies and their nonbank subsidiaries or affiliates ( except brokers, dealers, persons providing insurance, investment companies, and investment advisers ) ; ( C ) banks insured by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation ( other than members of the Federal Reserve System ), insured State branches of foreign banks, and any subsidiaries of such entities ( except brokers, dealers, persons providing insurance, investment companies, and investment advisers ) ; and ( D ) savings associations the deposits of which are insured by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, and any subsidiaries of such savings associations ( except brokers, dealers, persons providing insurance, investment companies, and investment advisers ).

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative:
As per the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), outlined in 15 USC 1681, it is imperative that consumer reporting agencies uphold their responsibilities with fairness, impartiality, and a deep regard for consumer privacy, as stated in 15 USC 1681 section 602 ( a ). XXXX, Experian, and XXXX function as consumer reporting agencies, while I am the Consumer. My right to safeguard my private information from dissemination is supported by 15 USC 6801, which underscores the obligation of financial institutions, including ( Furnisher of information to credit agencies ), to respect customer privacy and safeguard nonpublic personal information.

Referring to 15 USC 1681 section 604 ( a ), section 2, it is established that any consumer reporting agency may only furnish a consumer report with the written instructions of the concerned consumer. Both ( Furnisher of information to credit agencies ), the financial institution, and the consumer reporting agencies, XXXX, Experian, and XXXX, lack my consent, which includes verbal, non-verbal, written, implied, or any other form, and I hereby revoke any and all such consent. 

According to 15 USC 6802 ( b ) ( c ), a financial institution can not disclose nonpublic personal information to a nonaffiliated third party without providing the consumer an explanation of how to exercise the nondisclosure option. Unfortunately, ( Furnisher of information to credit agencies ) never informed me of my right to exercise this option.

Moreover, 15 USC 1681C ( a ) ( 5 ) explicitly prohibits consumer reporting agencies from including adverse items of information in consumer reports without authorization. This account, reported as an adverse item without my permission, violates this provision.

Under 15 U.S. Code 1681s2 ( A ) ( 1 ), it is unlawful to furnish inaccurate information to consumer reporting agencies. XXXX, Experian, and XXXX are failing to maintain reasonable procedures in line with this requirement. 

Additionally, 15 U.S. Code 1681e mandates that consumer reporting agencies maintain reasonable procedures to avoid violations of section 1681c and limit the furnishing of consumer reports to the purposes listed under section 1681b. XXXX, Experian, and XXXX are not adhering to these standards. 

In accordance with 12 CFR 1016.7, I am exercising my right to opt out of reporting services for the following accounts : XXXX XXXX XXXX ( ACCOUNT NUMBER : XXXX ) XXXX XXXX XXXX ( ACCOUNT NUMBER : XXXX ) XXXX XXXX ( ACCOUNT NUMBER : XXXX ) XXXX  ( ACCOUNT NUMBER : XXXX ) XXXX XXXX ( ACCOUNT NUMBER : XXXX ) XXXX XXXX ( ACCOUNT NUMBER : XXXX )

EXPERIAN ALSO ENGAGES IN THIS BEHAVIOR BECUASE THEY HAVE INSERTED THIS FRAUD ACCOUNT ON MY CREDIT REPORT Texas law gives someone a certain amount of time to bring a lawsuit for an unpaid debt. This time period is often commonly referred to as the statute of limitations.

Once the time period set out by the statute of limitations is up, a person is prohibited from filing suit to recover the debt. This means the debt is time-barred. 

In the past, taking certain actions such as making a payment or verbally acknowledging that you owe the debt could restart the clock on the limitations period. This created a problem called zombie debt where the time period set out by the statute of limitations could be constantly restarted. 

A new state law introduced in XXXX aims to protect people from zombie debt. This law prevents debt buyers from suing to try to collect the debt even if a payment is made on the debt after the statute of limitations has expired. It also requires debt buyers to provide written notice if they are taking action past the limitations period. Debt buyers are defined by Section XXXX of the XXXX XXXX XXXX as a person who purchases a consumers debt from a creditor. Please see the statute for a full definition. 

You still owe time-barred debts, but creditors and debt buyers lose their most powerful way of collecting a lawsuit.

Texas and Federal Law Section 16.004 of the Texas Civil Practice and Remedies Code The statute of limitations on debt in Texas is four years.

Section 392.307 of the Texas Finance Code This section of the law, introduced in XXXX, states that a payment on the debt ( or any other activity ) does not restart the clock on the statute of limitations for debt buyers. It also requires that debt buyers provide written notice to a consumer if the limitations period has expired. 
Title 12, Section 1006.26 of the Code of Federal Regulations New rules from the federal Consumer Financial Protection Bureau prevent debt collectors from suing or threatening to sue over time-barred debts. Debt collectors in this code are defined in section 1006.2 ( i ) and can include the original creditor if they are using a different name. 
Understanding the Law What is a statute of limitations on a debt? 
This page from the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau explains the concept of the statute of limitations and how it relates to debt. 
What is XXXX XXXX? 
This page explains the concept of " time-barred debts '' and suggests options for dealing with a creditor, third-party debt collector, or debt buyer trying to collect them. 
Debt Buyers Prohibited from Suing to Collect and Reviving Old Debts ( Texas XXXX ) This article describes the XXXX changes and provides legal aid options as well as links to legal forms. Texas XXXX is a nonprofit organization described as a " public interest justice center ''. 
XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX creditors, third-party debt collectors, or debt buyers will try to intimidate you into paying debts that are past the statute of limitations. Read this page from XXXX to learn your rights when it comes to these old debts. 


AND Texas Laws Against Aggressive Debt Collection When it comes to debt collection, consumers have a variety of options to protect themselves against unlawful debt collectors. A XXXX law in Texas strengthened the rights of consumers against debt collection and maintained the states short statute of limitations. A Texas statute of limitations on debt is the amount of time a company or person has to pursue legal action against another. If enough time has passed, then the statute of limitations means that companies can no longer sue people for their debts. Luckily, Texas has laws on the books to protect people against debt and the laws are in the favor of the consumer. With the help of an attorney, there are ways to overcome these lawsuits and defeat the creditors. 

When people receive letters or summons in the mail about an old unpaid debt, it can inspire fear and panic. A person in debt may still be in a position where they are unable to resolve the debt and the collection attempts can bring up trauma. In the case of old debts, or what some people call zombie debts because of how debt collectors never ceased to collect on them, companies can still aggressively attempt to collect on the debt. However, as a response to this, many states like Texas implement a statute of limitations to protect citizens who can not pay or do not want to pay the debt collector. 

What is the Texas Statue of Limitations?

The Statute of Limitations is a Texas law that states that if you owe unpaid debt such as credit card debt or consumer debt, the collector only has four years to bring a debt collection lawsuit against you. Bringing a Debt Lawsuit in a Texas Court is the debtor collectors strongest method for collecting. So removing this option for the creditor is significant. 

This Texas law is governed by Section XXXX of the Texas XXXX XXXX and Remedies Code. When you have a credit card, you have a contract with the credit card company where you promise to pay the credit card company. A written contract is not required. So if you stop paying the credit card, the credit card company can file a lawsuit against you to collect the debt under the theory of breach of contract. However, if the debt collector does not file a lawsuit within four years of the breach of contract, then they can not file the lawsuit to collect the debt. This debt is now known as time-barred debt. If the creditor files a lawsuit against you after the four years, they are violating the Texas Debt Collection Law, and you can initiate retaliatory legal action, and have a strong case for getting the lawsuit dismissed.

What Is Time Barred Debt? 
Time-barred debt is debt that can not be collected through legal action anymore due to the expiration of the 4-year statute of limitations. The creditor can still attempt to collect the debt and report it on your credit report, but they can not bring a lawsuit against you and so they can not obtain a Judgement against you either.

The company can no longer threaten to sue you and forcibly collect the old debt through a lawsuit before you can organize your finances. In essence, the bank can not force you to settle the debt before you are ready and can not drag an individual into court when it is clear the individual can not pay. 

Avoiding Illegal Collection Restarts It is also important to remember that this XXXX law also included a Section that introduced the idea of time-barred debt. Once the statute of limitations has passed on the debt in Texas, then collectors can not chase consumers for it. The old debts are considered time-barred, which means that they are off-limits. In some states, companies abuse their consumers by frightening the individuals into promising to pay their debts or even acknowledging the debts. This is a trick to allow the company the right to restart the clock on collections and continue harassing the person into payment. They call this zombie debt.

Luckily, Texas law contains provisions that outlaw companies from restarting the debt. Even if you attempt to pay the debt at one time, they can no longer threaten you with legal action. Although you may still owe the debt on the books unless you file for bankruptcy or settle with the company, they lose their most powerful weapon of intimidation thanks to powerful Texas laws that protect vulnerable consumers. 

How Do You Calculate The Statute Of Limitations? 
The statute of limitations is XXXX years since the date of the breach of the contract. So when does this breach actually happen? As a rule of thumb, the date of breach is about 30 days after the last time you paid the debt. 

To illustrate this, lets say you have a credit card bill where the minimum payment is due on the first day of each month. You pay your XX/XX/XXXX minimum payment and you are current on your credit card bill. Then you do not make your XX/XX/XXXX and all future subsequent payments. Your last payment was XX/XX/XXXX, but you did not breach your contract until at least XX/XX/XXXX when you missed your first credit card payment. So if a client presented these facts to me, I would advise them that the statute of limitations clock did not start counting until at least XX/XX/XXXX. When it is a close call like this, you should really get your ducks in a row by pulling your credit report and reviewing it to determine your last payment. 

Going into debt itself can be one of the most difficult things about adult life. If you find yourself facing a lawsuit or experiencing harassment over a debt that could potentially be barred by the statute of limitations, please dont hesitate to reach out to our law office. Were here to assist individuals facing financial difficulties. Our team can support you by actively challenging your creditors, exploring potential settlements, or providing guidance on the bankruptcy process. Rest assured, were dedicated to finding the right solution for your specific situation, and were here to help you in your fight against creditors.

AND What Debt Collectors Cant Do Debt collectors are regulated by the Texas Debt Collection Act. Among other things, the Act prohibits debt collectors from : Using abusive collection tactics, including : threatening violence or other criminal acts using profane or obscene language falsely accusing the consumer of fraud or other crimes threatening arrest of the consumer, or repossession or other XXXX of property without proper court proceedings using the telephone to harass debtors by calling anonymously or making repeated or continuous calls making collect telephone calls without disclosing the true name of the caller before the charges are accepted Using fraudulent collection tactics, including : using a false name or identification misrepresenting the amount of the debt or its judicial status sending documents to a debtor that falsely appear to be from a court or other official agency failing to identify who holds the debt misrepresenting the nature of the services rendered by the collection agency or the collector falsely representing that the collector has information or something of value in order to discover information about the consumer Trying to collect more than the amount originally agreed upon. ( But remember : your debt can grow by the addition of fees e.g., collection fees, attorney fees, etc. ). 
Violators of the Texas Debt Collection Act are subject to criminal and civil penalties. If you think you have been harassed or deceived, you can even seek injunctions and damages against debt collectors.

These actions are also violations of the Texas Deceptive Trade Practices/Consumer Protection Act, which gives the Attorney General the authority to take action in the public interest.

This process aims to determine the accuracy of the disputed information and update the current status within 30 days of receiving the consumer 's dispute notification. Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative:
Dear Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, I am writing to file a formal complaint regarding unauthorized inquiries on my credit report by XXXX, TransUnion, and XXXX. It appears that these inquiries were made without my written consent, in violation of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), specifically 15 U.S. Code 1681b.

The FCRA outlines permissible purposes for consumer reports, and one of these purposes, as stated in 15 U.S. Code 1681b ( 2 ), is to furnish a consumer report in accordance with the written instructions of the consumer to whom it relates. Furthermore, under P.L 90-321 ( 82 Stat. 146 ), which supports the FCRA, stricter provisions are in place to ensure that consumer reports are only obtained in response to specific requests authorized by certain government agencies.

I have not provided written consent for these inquiries, nor have I authorized any entity to request my credit report for the purposes for which these inquiries were made. As such, it appears that XXXX, TransUnion, and XXXX have violated the FCRA by furnishing my consumer report without my written instructions or consent. 

I would also like to bring your attention to the Privacy Act of 1974, particularly 5 U.S. Code 552a ( 4 ), which defines the term " record '' as any item, collection, or grouping of information about an individual maintained by an agency. This includes, but is not limited to, information about the individual 's education, financial transactions, medical history, and criminal or employment history.

I kindly request that the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau investigate this matter thoroughly and take appropriate action to address these unauthorized inquiries. Enclosed with this letter, you will find copies of relevant documents, including my credit report reflecting the unauthorized inquiries.

Thank you for your prompt attention to this issue. I trust that the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau will take the necessary steps to ensure that my rights under the FCRA are protected. 
XX/XX/XXXX

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Issue: Problem with a company's investigation into an existing problem
Sub-issue: Their investigation did not fix an error on your report
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to file a complaint regarding ongoing issues with the reporting of a collections account by XXXX XXXX XXXX, Experian, and XXXX. Having disputed this account since last year, and a minimum of fifteen attemps. XXXX has removed the account, but Experian and XXXX have not conducted thorough investigations, and I suspect multiple violations of proper procedures. 

The account was from a XXXX XXXX credit card, where my last payment was in XX/XX/XXXX. The account was charged off in XX/XX/XXXX, and in XX/XX/XXXX, I received a letter stating it had been voluntarily disposed of in civil court. As I was a New York resident, I believe this lawsuit occurred beyond the statute of limitations. I did not receive any letters from them until XXXX and did not know about this collections. I also do not see how they have any legal authority by disposal of the case themselves. 

Even after the account 's deletion from XXXX, XXXX continues to pull my credit report, potentially violating FCRA 604 ( f ) and FCRA 619. Moreover, their constant sale/forwarding of a debt buyer account to a factoring company account, appears to be a breach of contract according to the National Consumer Assistance Plan ( NCAP ) and the agreement between CRAs to not accept any data that did not arise from a contract or agreement to pay. They were also constantly closing, opening, and switching to a " retail '' account. 

Experian and XXXX show duplicate collection entries from XXXX, showing signs of re-aging. XXXX displays entirely fabricated, false payments, a missed payment, then current again, and constantly changing the " date of major delinquency first reported. '' Experian does not have the FCRA XXXXmpliance/DOFD on my credit file, while XXXX places it in the future, violating the FCRA 90-day reporting requirement. 

Despite many attempts to fix these issues, Experian denies duplicate collection entries and the existence of the NCAP agreement. Both Experian and XXXX claim they lack the legal authority to correct or remove inaccurate collections. XXXX has also removed the mandatory K1 Segment from my XXXX report, and there is no payment history from the original creditor on both agency 's. 

When my results came back from XXXX for the incorrect DOFD and false payments, it was not only verified as accurate, but XXXX themselves certified the account is being reported correctly. 

I would like to bring to your attention several of many potential violations with the reporting of the collections account by XXXX XXXX XXXX and the credit reporting agencies. I believe the following statutes and codes have been violated : False representation of the character, amount, or legal status of any debt ( 15 USC 1692e ( 2 ) ( A ) ).

False representation or implication that any individual is an attorney or that any communication is from an attorney ( 15 USC 1692e ( 3 ) ).

False representation or implication that a sale, referral, or other transfer of any interest in a debt shall cause the consumer to lose any claim or defense to payment of the debt ( 15 USC 1692e ( 6 ) ( A ) ).

Use of any false representation or deceptive means to collect or attempt to collect any debt or to obtain information concerning a consumer ( 15 USC 1692e ( 10 ) ).

False representation or implication that accounts have been turned over to innocent purchasers for value ( 15 USC 1692e ( 12 ) ).

Use or distribution of any written communication that simulates or falsely represents to be a document authorized, issued, or approved by any court, official, or agency of the United States or any State, or which creates a false impression as to its source, authorization, or approval ( 15 USC 1692e ( 9 ) ).

Use of any business, company, or organization name other than the true name of the debt collector 's business, company, or organization ( 15 USC 1692e ( 14 ) ).

Unfair practices under section 808 of the FDCPA. 

It is also worth noting that both Experian and XXXX have informed me that they do not provide a method of verification for past disputes, as required by the FCRA. 

These potential FCRA and FDCPA violations raise concerns about the accuracy, fairness, and legality of the actions taken by XXXX XXXX XXXX and the credit reporting agencies. I please ask that the CFPB to find a correction for this. 

Attached are my last dispute letters to Experian and XXXX, duplicated collections, XXXX false payments, with a false delinquency, XXXX credit file without the original creditor and falsely creditor classification as " retail. '' Date of civil court disposal, along with XXXX 's confirmation of the account 's deletion.
Company public response: Company has responded to the consumer and the CFPB and chooses not to provide a public response

Consumer complaint narrative:
Subject : Complaint Regarding Failure to Receive Promotional Bonus from U.S. Bank Dear Customer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ) Representative, I hope this email finds you well. I am writing to file a formal complaint against U.S. Bank for their failure to provide me with the promised promotional bonus, despite my having met all the specified requirements outlined in their promotional campaign. This issue pertains to a business checking account promotion that promised a significant reward for maintaining a certain deposit over a specified period. 

To summarize, I received an invitation from U.S. Bank on XX/XX/year>, to open a business checking account with the promise of a {$750.00} bonus for depositing {$15000.00} and maintaining it for over 60 days. I promptly met these requirements, only to be later informed that I supposedly did not fulfill another condition not previously communicated to me. 

For your convenience, I have included several attachments with this email : At attached documents include my checking account approved proof screenshot and 6 month bank statement of this account. 

Despite numerous attempts to resolve this issue directly with U.S. Bank, including multiple communications with their customer service department and provision of all requested documentation, my efforts have been fruitless. It has now been several months since I satisfied all promotional criteria, yet the promised bonus remains uncredited. 

This refusal to honor a clear promotional commitment not only constitutes a breach of agreement but also represents a broader issue of trust and integrity within the banking sector. I am therefore reaching out to the CFPB to seek assistance in resolving this matter, ensuring that U.S. Bank is held accountable for their promotional practices. 

I believe the CFPB 's commitment to ensuring fair banking practices and protecting consumer rights positions it uniquely to address and rectify this situation. I am hopeful for your support in securing the promotional bonus rightfully owed to me by U.S. Bank. 

Thank you very much for your attention to this important matter. I am eager for a resolution and remain available should you need any further information or clarification. 

Sincerely, XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative:
My identity has been stolen you are hereby put on notice. 
Aggravated Identity Theft pursuant to 18 U.S.C. 1028A.

( 1 ) In general. 
Whoever, during and in relation to any felony violation enumerated in subsection ( c ), knowingly transfers, possesses, or uses, without lawful authority, a means of identification of another person shall, in addition to the punishment provided for such felony, be sentenced to a term ofimprisonment of 2 years. 
An identification of me has been used with out my permission to open several accounts that have damaged my reputation and damaged my mode of living because you furnished a consumer report without my written permission as stated by Federal Law 15 USC 1681b Permissible purpose of consumer reports ( a ) IN GENERAL Subject to subsection ( c ) any consumer reporting agency may furnish a consumer report under the following circumstances and no other : ( 2 ) In accordance with the written instructions of the consumer to whom it relates. 
YOU XXXX, XXXX, EXPERIAN have aided this Fraud by not verifying these accounts. 
Congress states 15 USC 1681 Fair Credit Reporting Act ( a ) Accuracy and fairness of credit reports ( 4 ) There is a need to insure that consumer reporting agencies exercise their grave responsibilities with fairness, impartiality, and a respect for the consumers right to privacy. 
List Account/s here : Account Name : XXXX XXXX Account Number : XXXX Reason : Unverified account Pursuant 15 U.S. Code 1681c2 - Block of information resulting from identity theft Except as otherwise provided in this section, a consumer reporting agency shall block the reporting of anyinformation in the file of a consumer that the consumer identifies as information that resulted from an alleged identity theft, not later than 4 business days after the date of receipt by such agency of ( 1 ) appropriate proof of the identity of the consumer ; ( 2 ) a copy of an identity theft report ; ( 3 ) the identification of such information by the consumer ; and ( 4 ) a statement by the consumer that the information is not information relating to any transaction by the consumer. 
I have attached all the relevant documents pursuant the above Section of the law. 
I demand all the above Fraudulent accounts DELETED immediately. 
I Demand an updated copy of my Consumer file reflecting these changes ( 15 USC 1681 c-1 2 Access to free reports ) ( 2 ) Access to free reports In any case in which a consumer reporting agency includes a fraud alert in the file of a consumer pursuant to this subsection, the consumer reporting agency shall ( A ) disclose to the consumer that the consumer may request a free copy of the file of the consumer pursuant to section 1681j ( d ) of this title ; and Be Advised I will CC The Bureau of Consumer Protection Financial ( CFPB ) FTC XXXX Attorney Generals Office in your state and Mine Thank you, XXXX XXXX FTC reference number XXXX

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to you regarding a violation of my privacy and confidentiality rights, protected under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( 15 USC 1681b ( 2 ) ). Pursuant to 18 USC 8, I have identified the following accounts that have breached these legal provisions : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  These accounts have accessed my credit information without my explicit authorization, which constitutes a violation of my privacy and confidentiality rights. Additionally, some of these accounts contain obsolete information that should be excluded from my credit report as stipulated in 15 USC 1681c ( a ) ( 5 ).

According to 15 USC 1681, Section 602 ( A ), I have the right to privacy. Furthermore, under 15 USC 1681, Section 604 ( A ), Section 2, a consumer reporting agency can not furnish an account without my written instructions. Also, 15 USC 1681c ( a ) ( 5 ) states that no consumer reporting agency may include any adverse item of information that is more than seven years old, other than records of convictions of crimes.

Finally, under 15 USC 1681s-2 ( a ) ( 1 ), no person shall furnish any information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if the person knows or has reasonable cause to believe that the information is inaccurate. Additionally, according to 15 USC 1681s-2 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( B ), a person shall not furnish information if ( i ) the person has been notified by the consumer that specific information is inaccurate, and ( ii ) the information is, in fact, inaccurate.

They are not in compliance with the following law. 15 USC 1666b and its requirements set the standards and the guidance for a creditor to treat a payment as late, yet they are reporting a payment as late and they did not comply with the law!

15 USC 1666b ( a ) Time to make payments A creditor may not treat a payment on a credit card account under an open end consumer credit plan as late for any purpose, unless the creditor has adopted reasonable procedures designed to ensure that each periodic statement including the information required by section 1637 ( b ) of this title is mailed or delivered to the consumer not later than 21 days before the payment due date.

Never Sent the periodic statement along with the disclosures from section 1637 ( b ).

I have requested proof that this information was mailed or delivered 21 days before the payment due date and this information was requested in good faith pursuant rule 1002 and It was never provided.

This is unfair, illegal, fraudulent, and not equitable to me as a consumer!

Delete the late payments from my consumer reports

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to file a formal complaint against XXXX XXXX regarding their unauthorized sharing of my nonpublic personal information with non-affiliated third parties and consumer reporting agencies. I have taken the appropriate steps to exercise my rights under 15 USC 6802 of the Gramm-Leach- Bliley Act ( GLBA ) to opt out of such information sharing and I believe my privacy rights have been violated. 

On XX/XX/year> I notified XXXX XXXX that I am opting out of any and all authorizations, written, non-written verbal or non-verbal for the sharing of my nonpublic personal information with non-affiliated 3rd parties, including consumer reporting agencies for any purpose other than those necessary to provide me with financial products of services. 

I provided this opt out notice in accordance with the legal requirements outlined in 15 USC 6802, and I have retained documentation of my communication with XXXX XXXX 

Despite my efforts to request an opt out and me asserting my rights under GLBA, I have reason to believe that XXXX XXXX has continued to furnish my non public personal information to nonaffiliated 3rd parties and consumer reporting agencies without my consent. 

The unauthorized use of my personal information constitutes a violation of my privacy rights and breach of federal law. I am concerned about the potential consequences of this unathorized sharing, including the potential for identity theft, fraud, and other financial harm. 

I would appreciate it if the CFPB can investigate this matter thoroughly and take appropriate action to ensure that XXXX XXXX complies with all federal regulations and laws, including the GLBA to protect privacy and security of consumers like me. 

I would also appreciate updates on the progress of this investigation and actions taken to address the violations committed by XXXX XXXX. 

Please feel free to contact me at XXXX or email me at XXXX if you require any further information or documents to proceed with the investigation. 

see enclosed letter sent to the XXXX XXXX XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative: Per the Fair Credit Reporting Agency as a federally protected consumer I am now opting out of any and all authorization I the consumer may have given written, unwritten, verbal and non verbal Per 15 USC 6802. According to 15 USC Code 1681b Permissible purposes of consumer reports they need written consent to add anything to your consumer report this is a violation of the Fair Credit Reporting Act. 15 USC code 1681a reporting transaction history is illegal. 12 CFR 1016.1 Purpose and scope provides a method for consumers to prevent financial institutions from disclosing information to affiliated third parties by opting out of that disclosure. I have the right to make sure my private information is not shared which is backed by 15 USC 6801. It is the policy of the Congress that each financial institution has an affirmative and continuing obligation to respect the privacy of its customers and to protect the security and confidentiality of customers non public information. XXXX, Experian, XXXX XXXX are not maintaining reasonable procedures. Also 12 CFR 1016.7 states that A consumer may exercise the right to opt out of your reporting services. I am not opting out of your reporting services.
