Product: Credit card
Sub-product: General-purpose credit card or charge card
Issue: Problem with a purchase shown on your statement
Sub-issue: Credit card company isn't resolving a dispute about a purchase on your statement
Consumer complaint narrative: In XX/XX/year>, I had contacted XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX ( XXXX ), a Canadian company, to ask questions I had about an upcoming trip where I had to visit Canada. XXXX XXXX and Waiver Services mislead me, telling me I needed paperwork to enter Canada that I later found out was not needed. When speaking with XXXX, I was advised that they would be adding 2 services to my file because it looks better, but I can cancel the 2nd service after receiving the first but would have to wait until XXXX. I specifically asked if I could cancel after my trip in XXXX, they said yes. After my trip in XXXX, I called to cancel the second service and after being passed around to multiple people, I was told they are refusing my request. I asked them to review our calls where I was specifically told I had to wait until after XXXX to cancel, but could cancel after XXXX. They reviewed the calls, ADMITTED I was told this information, but told me they are not going to refund me. I was also on a payment plan for 10 months starting in XXXX, but was charged in full over XXXX transactions in XXXX. I contacted Apple Card Services ( Goldman Sachs bank ) to dispute the charge. There was some confusion as the charge was for {$2000.00} CAN, and it was spread out over 2 payments. Because I was being charged for 2 services but only proceeded with one, I was only trying to dispute the one service. My dispute is repeatedly being denied, although multiple customer service agents assure me it will be taken care of. I have sent information over and over including the payment plan that I was supposed to be charged for, the paperwork that was never completed, and the initial paperwork I signed stating it can be canceled at any point. This is for the {$2000.00} CAN on the paperwork, as I was not disputing the {$1600.00} charge ( which are the first 2 {$800.00} showing on the payment plan ). Although I was mislead about both services, they did the work for the {$1600.00} service NOT the {$2000.00} service.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative: RE : Late Payment Improperly Reported- I XXXX XXXX have a RIGHT TO PRIVACY under 15 USC 1681A ( 4 ) as a federally protected consumer and I know my rights presented under the Fair Credit Reporting Act clearly outlined within 15 USC 1681. The Fair Credit Reporting Act ( 15 U.S. Code 1681 ) says ( 1 ) The banking system is dependent upon fair and accurate credit reporting. Inaccurate credit reports directly impair the efficiency of the banking system, and unfair credit reporting methods undermine the public confidence which is essential to the continued functioning of the banking system. So, whenever there is a violation under the FCRA, it impairs the efficiency of the banking system. This is a violation of my privacy with my consumer report, since I control what is listed and what is not. In the event that any accounts are reported without my written consent, that is considered identity theft. This is a violation of both 15 U.S. Code 1681b ( 2 ) and 15 U.S. Code 1681c-2. This leads way to civil liability against the credit reporting agency for negligent and willful noncompliance under 15 U.S. Code 1681n and 15 USC 1681o, which allows for {$1000.00} per violation, for account listed without my expressed written consent. I was reviewing my consumer reports and noticed XXXX XXXX XXXX on my credit report that need be immediately updated to paid as agreed. My Consumer rights have been violated by XXXX, XXXX, Experian. XXXX, XXXX, Experian has violated my consumer rights and violated federal law. There have been Many attempts to notify you of this erroneous error on the part of your agency. This erroneous late payment is affecting my ability to obtain a loan to save my business from crumbling and also blocking me from the housing that I so desperately need for myself and my family. Please change this to paid as agreed immediately so that I may proceed with my life, or I may be forced to seek legal damages against your agency as I already have sought legal counsel in this more than important matter. Thank you.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Consumer complaint narrative:
XX/XX/year> Subject : Request for Removal of Late Payment Record Dear XXXX, I hope this letter finds you well. I am writing to formally request the removal of a late payment entry associated with my account XXXX under the provisions of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ). 


According to 15 U.S. Code 1681s-2, creditors have an obligation to report accurate information to credit reporting agencies. I believe that the late payments were reported on XX/XX/year> does not accurately reflect my payment history, and therefore violates this provision. 


Furthermore, under 15 U.S. Code 1666b and 15 U.S. Code 1681i, I have the right to dispute any inaccuracies and to have them investigated. I request that you review my payment history and consider removing the late payment from my credit report. I have always valued my relationship with XXXX  and have made all my payments on time, except for this instance, which I have identified several factors that suggest an error in the reporting process : Timely Payments : I have consistently made on-time payments throughout the life of the loan, and I have documentation that supports this. The late payment reported for XX/XX/year> does not align with my payment history, which indicates no missed or late payments prior to this instance. 
Payment Processing Delay : The payment for XX/XX/year> was submitted within the required timeframe, but there may have been an internal delay in processing, leading to the incorrect reporting of a late payment.

Dispute Already Filed : I had previously filed a dispute regarding this issue, which was marked as resolved. However, the inaccurate late payment entry remains on my credit report, which has negatively impacted my credit score.

I kindly ask that you provide me with a response to this request within 30 days. Should you find that the information reported is incorrect, I would appreciate your assistance in correcting it with the credit reporting agencies. 
Thank you for your attention to this matter. I look forward to your prompt response. 


Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX
Company public response: Company has responded to the consumer and the CFPB and chooses not to provide a public response

XXXX XXXX  can not collect on a discharged debt. This is now considered a certificate of indebtedness per the IRS and income can not be reported. XXXX XXXX has been HEREBY PUT ON NOTICE that they are furnishing incorrect inaccurate information. In XXXX XXXX terms and conditions they agreed not to share my information with non affiliates. Experian, XXXX, and XXXX is not an affiliate of XXXX XXXX nor are they " bureaus ''. The only true credit bureau is the CFPB and they DO NOT furnish consumer reports as stated in federal law. I have a right to privacy and Per the Privacy Act of 1974 as a federally protected consumer I am now revoking any and all authorization I the consumer XXXX have given you written, non written, verbal, and nonverbal per 5 U.S. Code 552a. Per the FCRA as a federally protected consumer I am now opting out of any and all authorization I the consumer XXXX have given you written, non written, verbal, and non verbal per 15 USC 6802. I shall also point out their responsibility pursuant 15 U.S. Code section 1681s-2 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( B ) ( ii ) : ( a ) DUTY OF FURNISHERS OF INFORMATION TO PROVIDE ACCURATE INFORMATION XXXX ) PROHIBITION ( B ) Reporting information after notice and confirmation of errors A person shall not furnish information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if ( i ) the person has been notified by the consumer, at the address specified by the person for such notices, that specific information is inaccurate ; and ( ii ) the information is, in fact, inaccurate. XXXX XXXX must also refund the remaining balance of the consumer account upon its termination. This is your 7 day notice to return ALL money due from this consum er account. 1026.11 Treatment of credit balances ; account termination. ( a ) Credit balances. When a credit balance in excess of { { {$1.00} } } is created on a credit account ( through transmittal of funds to a creditor in excess of the total balance due on an account, through rebates of unearned finance charges or insurance premiums, or through amounts otherwise owed to or held for the benefit of the consumer ), the creditor shall : ( 1 ) Credit the amount of the credit balance to the consumer 's account ; ( 2 ) Refund any part of the remaining credit balance within seven business days from receipt of a written request from the consumer ; ( XXXX ) Make a good faith effort to refund to the consumer by cash, check, or money order, or credit to a deposit account of the consumer, any part of the credit balance remaining in the account for more than XXXX months. No further action is required if the consumer 's current location is not known to the creditor and can not be traced through the consumer 's last known address or telephone number. ( b ) Account termination. ( XXXX ) A creditor shall not terminate an account prior to its expiration date solely because the consumer does not incur a finance charge. ( XXXX ) Nothing in paragraph ( b ) ( XXXX ) of this section prohibits a creditor from terminating an account that is inactive for XXXX or more consecutive months. An account is inactive for purposes of this paragraph if no credit has been extended ( such as by purchase, cash advance or balance transfer ) and if the account has no outstanding balance. ( c ) Timely settlement of estate debts ( XXXX ) General rule. ( i ) Reasonable policies and procedures required. For credit card accounts under an open-end ( not home-secured ) consumer credit plan, card issuers must adopt reasonable written policies and procedures designed to ensure that an administrator of an estate of a deceased accountholder can determine the amount of and pay any balance on the account in a timely manner. ( ii ) Application to joint accounts. Paragraph ( c ) of this section does not apply to the account of a deceased consumer if a joint accountholder remains on the account. ( 2 ) Timely statement of balance ( i ) Requirement. Upon request by the administrator of an estate, a card issuer must provide the administrator with the amount of the balance on a deceased consumer 's account in a timely manner. ( ii ) Safe harbor. For purposes of paragraph ( c ) ( 2 ) ( i ) of this section, providing the amount of the balance on the account within 30 days of receiving the request is deemed to be timely. ( 3 ) Limitations after receipt of request from administrator ( i ) Limitation on fees and increases in annual percentage rates. After receiving a request from the administrator of an estate for the amount of the balance on a deceased consumer 's account, a card issuer must not impose any fees on the account ( such as a late fee, annual fee, or over-the-limit fee ) or increase any annual percentage rate, except as provided by 1026.55 ( b ) ( 2 ). ( ii ) Limitation on trailing or residual interest. A card issuer must waive or rebate any additional finance charge due to a periodic interest rate if payment in full of the balance disclosed pursuant to paragraph ( c ) ( 2 ) of this section is received within 30 days after disclosure.

Consumer complaint narrative:
XX/XX/XXXX Subject : Complaint Regarding Inaccurate Late Payment Entry on Credit Report Dear CFPB, I am writing to file a formal complaint against Experian regarding an inaccurate late payment entry on my credit report that has not been resolved despite my attempts to rectify the issue. 

Account Information : Creditor 's Name : XXXX Account Number : XXXX Dates of Late Payments : XX/XX/XXXX Nature of Complaint : I submitted a dispute to Experian disputing a late payment reported by XXXX  I referenced the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( 15 U.S. Code 1681i ) and the Truth in Lending Act ( TILA ) ( 15 U.S. Code 1637 ( b ) ) in my dispute, explaining that the reported late payment was inaccurate for the following reasons : Payment Delay Due to a Bank Transfer Error : My payment for XX/XX/XXXX was initiated on time. However, a processing error on my bank 's end delayed the transfer by 24 hours. I provided bank statements and transfer confirmation showing the exact date the payment was initiated and the error acknowledged by my bank. 
System Outage on Payment Portal : During the period in question, XXXX experienced an outage on their online payment portal, which prevented me from making a timely payment through the usual online process. I contacted customer service immediately after the issue and have attached screenshots of my conversation with their support team confirming the technical outage. 
Incorrect Late Payment Assignment : The late payment was incorrectly applied to my account even though my payment history shows that I have consistently made on-time payments. There was no valid reason for the assignment of a late fee or the reporting of this late payment, and I have attached payment receipts that show consistent payments for the past two years.

Despite providing this information and adhering to the dispute process within the Fair Credit Reporting Act, Experian has failed to resolve this matter satisfactorily or remove the inaccurate late payment from my credit report.

As a consumer, I have rights under the FCRA and TILA, including the right to accurate credit reporting. The continued presence of this inaccurate information is negatively impacting my credit score and financial well-being.

Requested Resolution : I kindly request that the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau investigate this matter and take appropriate action to ensure that credit reporting agencies adhere to the Fair Credit Reporting Act and the Truth in Lending Act. 

Thank you for your attention to this important matter. I look forward to your prompt response regarding the investigation of my complaint. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative:
Consumer Financial Protection Bureau Subject : Complaint against XXXX for Violations of FDCPA and FCRA. 


Dear CFPB Employee, I am writing to file a formal complaint against XXXX for their repeated refusal to respond to my disputes, thereby violating the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ) and the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ). Under these laws, XXXX is obligated to respond to my disputes and delete the disputed account if they fail to respond within 30 days. 

Details of the Complaint : 1.The FDCPA Violation : Despite my multiple attempts to communicate with XXXX regarding a disputed alleged debt, I have received no response whatsoever. This complete disregard for the FDCPA 's requirement to address consumer disputes in a timely manner is unacceptable. 
2. The FCRA Violation : According to the FCRA, any entity that fails to respond to a dispute within 30 days must delete the disputed item from the consumer report. However, XXXX refusal to acknowledge my disputes and their failure to act within the legally mandated time frame goes against this crucial consumer protection legislation. 

I have made several attempts to resolve this matter directly with XXXX, but their lack of response has left me with no alternative but to escalate my complaint to you.

15 U.S. Code 1681- Congressional findings and statement of purpose a ) Accuracy and fairness of credit reporting The Congress makes the following findings : ( 4 ) There is a need to ensure that consumer reporting agencies exercise their grave responsibilities with fairness, impartiality, and a respect for the consumers right to privacy. 
( b ) Reasonable procedures It is the purpose of this subchapter to require that consumer reporting agencies adopt reasonable procedures for meeting the needs of commerce for consumer credit, personnel, insurance, and other information in a manner which is fair and equitable to the consumer, with regard to the confidentiality, accuracy, relevancy, and proper utilization of such information in accordance with the requirements of this subchapter. 
15 U.S. Code 1681b - Permissible purposes of consumer reports Subject to subsection ( c ), any consumer reporting agency may furnish a consumer report under the following circumstances and no other ( 2 ) In accordance with the written instructions of the consumer to whom it relates.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative:
In accordance with the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) 15 USC 1681, section 602a underscores the necessity for consumer reporting agencies to carry out their significant duties with fairness, impartiality, and a regard for the consumer 's entitlement to privacy. XXXX and Experian, recognized as consumer reporting agencies, interface directly with consumers like me. I, as the consumer, possess the fundamental right to safeguard my private information from unwarranted sharing, as substantiated by 15 USC 6801, which underscores Congress 's stance that each financial institution bears an ongoing obligation to uphold the privacy of its clientele and safeguard the confidentiality of their nonpublic personal data.

Entities furnishing information to credit agencies are categorized as financial institutions under the aforementioned statute. Pertinently, 15 USC 1681, section 604a, subsection 2 outlines that consumer reporting agencies may solely furnish consumer reports in adherence to the explicit written directives of the concerned consumer. Both the financial institution, as the provider of information to credit agencies, and the consumer reporting agencies such as XXXX and Experian, and XXXX, do not possess my authorization to furnish this information, nor do they have my explicit written consent. Therefore, any consent previously extended to XXXX, Experian, XXXX, or other entities acting as furnishers of information to credit agencies, whether verbal, non-verbal, written, implied, or otherwise, is hereby revoked. 
Moreover, 15 USC 6802 ( b ) ( c ) dictates that a financial institution must not disclose nonpublic personal information to nonaffiliated third parties unless the consumer is provided with a clear explanation of how they can exercise their right to non-disclosure. Regrettably, the financial institution in question failed to inform me of my right to exercise this option. Additionally, as per 15 USC 1681C ( a ) ( 5 ), no consumer reporting agency may include certain adverse items of information in a consumer report without proper authorization, a provision this account infringes upon.

Under 15 U.S. Code 1681s2 ( A ) ( 1 ), entities are prohibited from furnishing inaccurate information to consumer reporting agencies, yet XXXX and Experian continue to do so. Furthermore, 15 U.S. Code 1681e mandates that consumer reporting agencies maintain reasonable procedures to prevent violations of section 1681c and restrict the furnishing of consumer reports to the purposes specified under section 1681b, a requirement which XXXX and Experian seem to neglect. 
Additionally, as outlined in 12 CFR 1016.7, consumers retain the right to opt out of reporting services at any given time. Hence, I am formally exercising my right to opt out of your reporting services effective immediately.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Issue: Problem with a company's investigation into an existing problem
Sub-issue: Their investigation did not fix an error on your report
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to formally dispute inaccurate information being reported on my credit report regarding a charge-off. The account in question is listed as follows : Creditor : XXXX  XXXX Account Number : XXXX Date of Charge-Off : XXXX It has come to my attention that the charge-off is being reported month after month on my payment history, which is incorrect. According to the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), negative information such as a charge-off should only be reported once, corresponding to the date it was charged off. 
The FCRA requires that credit reporting agencies ensure the accuracy of the information they report ( 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ) ). Repeatedly reporting the charge-off each month results in a misleading and inaccurate credit report, which has significantly harmed my credit score.

Additionally, the statute of limitations for reporting a charge-off is seven years from the date of the first delinquency that led to the charge-off ( 15 U.S.C. 1681c ( a ) ( 4 ) ). Continuously reporting this charge-off as a new event each month does not reset the statute of limitations and is improper.

I request that you promptly investigate this account and correct the inaccurate information by removing the repeated entries of the charge-off from my payment history. Please update my credit report accordingly and provide me with a confirmation of these corrections. 
Thank you for your prompt attention to this matter

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Issue: Problem with a company's investigation into an existing problem
Sub-issue: Their investigation did not fix an error on your report
Consumer complaint narrative:
To Whom It May Concern, I am writing to file a formal complaint against EXPERIAN for their failure to remove fraudulent accounts from my credit report as required by law. 
I recently disputed several accounts on my credit report under the claim of identity theft, pursuant to 15 U.S.C. 1681c-2. I submitted a Police Report and an FTC identity theft report ( FTC Report Number : XXXX ) as evidence. The credit bureau acknowledged my dispute but has not complied with the requirements set forth by the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ). 
Despite my initial request for the blocking of these fraudulent items, the following account remain on my credit report : 1. XXXX XXXX XXXX - ACCOUNT NUMBERXXXX DateOpened:XX/XX/XXXX Date Report : XX/XX/XXXX.

15 U.S.C. 1681i ( 7 ) - Description of Investigation : Pursuant to the FCRA, credit reporting agencies are obligated to provide a description of the investigation within 15 days of receiving a consumer 's dispute. To date, I have not received this required information.

15 U.S.C. 609 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( a ) - Verification Requirement : Per the FCRA, you are required by federal law to verify all accounts and public information through physical verification of the original signed consumer contract and/or judgment ( s ). Without such verification, there is a risk that erroneous or fraudulent information could be included in credit reports. Given the lack of adequate verification, I request the removal of this unauthorized public record information.

Accuracy Compliance : Additionally, under 15 U.S. Code 1681e ( b ), you are required to follow reasonable procedures to ensure maximum possible accuracy of the information in my credit report. If the information can not be verified, per 15 U.S. Code 1681i ( a ) ( 5 ), I request that you delete any unverifiable information.

Failure to Investigate Accurately ( 15 U.S. Code 1681i ) : After submitting a dispute regarding inaccuracies on my credit report, I did not receive a thorough investigation within the mandated 30-day timeframe. The results of the investigation did not adequately address my concerns.

According to 15 U.S.C. 1681c-2, credit reporting agencies are required to block disputed information identified as resulting from identity theft within four business days of receiving a valid identity theft report. Additionally, under 15 U.S.C. 609 ( a ) ( 2 ) and 1681i ( 7 ), any unverifiable or inaccurate information must be removed from my credit report.

Inadequate Compliance Procedures ( 15 U.S. Code 1681e ( b ) ) : The bureau has not demonstrated that it has implemented reasonable procedures to ensure the accuracy and completeness of the information provided on my report. I am requesting detailed information on the procedures used during the investigation.

I demand that the CFPB investigate this matter and take appropriate action to ensure that these fraudulent accounts are deleted from my credit report. I expect a prompt resolution to this issue and would appreciate any guidance you can provide regarding my rights in this matter.

Thank you for your attention to this urgent issue. 
Sincerely, XXXX XXXX

The Fair Credit Reporting Act 15 USC 1681 section 602 ( a ) states " There is a need to insure that consumer reporting agencies exercise their grave responsibilities with fairness, impartiality, and a respect for the consumers right to privacy. ''Experian and XXXX are consumer reporting agencies, and I am the Consumer. 
15 U.S. Code 1681e states ''Every consumer reporting agency shall maintain reasonable procedures designed to avoid violations of section 1681c of this title and to limit the furnishing of consumer reports to the purposes listed under section 1681b of this title. These procedures shall require that prospective users of the information identify themselves, certify the purposes for which the information is sought, and certify that the information will be used for no other purpose. Every consumer reporting agency shall make a reasonable effort to verify the identity of a new prospective user and the uses certified by such prospective user prior to furnishing such user a consumer report. No consumer reporting agency may furnish a consumer report to any person if it has reasonable grounds for believing that the consumer report will not be used for a purpose listed in section 1681b of this title. Whenever a consumer reporting agency prepares a consumer report it shall follow reasonable procedures to assure maximum possible accuracy of the information concerning the individual about whom the report relates. Product: Payday loan, title loan, personal loan, or advance loan
Consumer complaint narrative:
On XX/XX/ in good faith, using my Credit card ( XXXX ) I applied for a personal line of credit via Upstarts website. The amount requested was XXXX. My request was denied and upstart sent me an adverse action via email. I received no benefit from this unauthorized use of my credit which makes it fraudulent activity! 
Credit is the right granted by the natural person meaning I am the ORIGINAL CREDITOR. Which means I can not be denied my own credit and I am being discriminated against by UPSTART. In response I sent them and adverse action dispute letter only for them to elaborate on reasons why my application was denied due to company policies. Those policies do not over power federal law. I will seek litigation for the following reasons if my transaction is not approved immediately. 
Refer to 15 USC 1602 ( f ) CREDIT, ( g ) CREDITOR, ( i ) CONSUMER, ( l ) CREDIT CARD, ( p ) UNAUTHORIZED USE ( f ) term credit means the right granted by a creditor to a debtor to defer payment of debt or to incur debt and defer its payment. 
( g ) The term creditor refers only to a person who both ( 1 ) regularly extends, whether in connection with loans, sales of property or services, or otherwise, consumer credit which is payable by agreement i ) The adjective consumer, used with reference to a credit transaction, characterizes the transaction as one in which the party to whom credit is offered or extended is a natural person, ( l ) The term credit card means any card, plate, coupon book or other credit device existing for the purpose of obtaining money, property, labor, or services on credit ( p ) The term unauthorized use as used in section 1643 of this title, means a use of a credit card by a person other than the cardholder who does not have actual, implied, or apparent authority for such use and from which the cardholder receives no benefit.

15 U.S. Code 1611- Criminal liability for willful and knowing violation Whoever willfully and knowingly ( 1 ) gives false or inaccurate information or fails to provide information which he is required to disclose under the provisions of this subchapter or any regulation issued thereunder, ( 2 ) uses any chart or table authorized by the Bureau under section 1606 of this title in such a manner as to consistently understate the annual percentage rate determined under section 1606 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ) of this title, or ( 3 ) otherwise fails to comply with any requirement imposed under this subchapter, shall be fined not more than {$5000.00} or imprisoned not more than one year, or both.

We have unsuccessfully contacted Freedom Mortgage insurance department over the phone and vial e-mails. Our VA mortgage loan was initially with XXXX  XXXX and we closed on a VA loan on XX/XX/year>XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX only required us to have homeowner and flood insurance policies, which we obtained. XXXX XXXXXXXX sold our mortgage loan to Freedom Mortgage a few months after our closing date. 
On XX/XX/year>, Freedom Mortgage charged {$5900.00}, to our escrow funds for a lender forced insurance without our awareness and consent. Once I became aware on or about XX/XX/year> of the forced charge into our escrow funds, immediately obtained wind insurance to replace the forced and expensive insurance policy of Freedom Mortgage and provided copy to Freedom Mortgage via e-mail on XX/XX/year>, and requested a refund of the forced insurance. 
On XX/XX/year>, Freedom Mortgage charged to our escrow funds the wind insurance policy we provided proof of in the amount of {$2600.00}. However, this amount had been already paid when the policy was taken. A refund in the amount of {$2600.00} is due to us either by Freedom Mortgage. 
On XX/XX/year>, Freedom Mortgage charged to our escrow funds another wind insurance policy in the amount of {$3600.00}, which we had obtained, paid for, and quickly cancelled. On XX/XX/year>, a copy of the cancellation of this paid insurance was e-mailed to Freedom Mortgage requesting a refund, which it has not happened. 
On XX/XX/year>, I contacted Freedom Mortgage again to request a refund for {$5900.00}, and I was told that the refund is to be pro-rated from XX/XX/year> to XX/XX/year>. 
Why are we being penalized by Freedom Mortgage and charged for a wind insurance policy we were NOT aware of from XX/XX/year> to XX/XX/year>? 
All calls and e-mails to Freedom Mortgage are being ignored and no refund has been provided to us nor to our escrow funds. 
Please investigate this type of fraud by a mortgage institution against veterans that served this country. 
We request that Freedom Mortgage issue a refund of the entire forced insurance for {$5900.00} because we were NOT aware and it was charged without our consent ; and refunds of the other XXXX insurance policies paid out of escrow in the amount of {$2600.00} and {$3600.00}. 
I can provide copies of all e-mail and attachments sent to Freedom Mortgage upon request.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports

Consumer complaint narrative: XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX  XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XX/XX/2023 I'm writing to say that the law, called the Fair Credit Reporting Act, protects my privacy. It says that companies like XXXX and XXXX, which share people 's financial information, must be fair and respect my privacy. Another law, 15 USC 6801, says that financial institutions, like the ones sharing my information, have to protect my privacy. I don't want them to share my information, and they need my permission to do so. Even if they had my permission before, I'm taking it back now. 15 USC 6802 says that a financial institution can't share my private information unless they explain how I can say no. They never told me I could say no. Moreover, another law, 15 USC 1681C, says that they can't share negative information about me without my permission. But they're doing it anyway, which is against the law. There are more laws, like 15 U.S. Code 1681s2 and 15 U.S. Code 1681e, that say companies like XXXX and XXXX must be careful and accurate when sharing information. But it seems like they're not following those rules. One more thing, according to 12 CFR 1016.7, I can choose not to let them share my information at any time. So, I'm choosing not to let them do it anymore. Thank you for understanding. Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative:
In accordance with the Fair Credit Reporting act. The List of accounts below has violated my federally protected consumer rights to privacy and confidentiality under 15 USC 1681.

15 U.S.C 1681 section 602 A. States I have the right to privacy.

15 U.S.C 1681 Section 604 A Section 2 : It also states a consumer reporting agency can not furnish a account without my written instructions 15 U.S.C 1681c. ( a ) ( 5 ) Section States : no consumer reporting agency may make any consumer report containing any of the following items of information Any other adverse item of information, other than records of convictions of crimes which antedates the report by more than seven years.

15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( A ) ( 1 ) A person shall not furnish any information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if the person knows or has reasonable cause to believe that the information is inaccurate.

Product: Credit reporting, credit repair services, or other personal consumer reports
Consumer complaint narrative:
My name is XXXX XXXX, I was not a person who believes in using credit cards and I always used debit as a primary payment method. Until recently my wife and I are planning on buying a house, so I checked my credit report and realized I have been a victim of identity theft for many years. I found two fraudulent accounts, one is a charge off from XXXX  XXXX XXXX in the amount of {$11000.00}, the other is an account in collection by XXXX XXXX XXXX originated from XXXX in the amount of {$4500.00}. Additionally, there's also two fraudulent hard inquires from XXXX XXXX and XXXX. 

It is a grave mistake on my part to not close guard my credit as seriously as I should, until it became a giant road block on my path to finally become a homeowner and realizing my American dream. Identity theft has put me in a very tough situation, I hope we can get the fraudulent activities off my credit report as soon as possible. 

Thank you, XXXX XXXX

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative:
Ive noticed that several deviations from mandatory reporting standards therefore the data in my report can not be accurate and complete! With that said, I deny your allegations and I challenge you to provide proof that you have the right to report this incomplete negative information on my credit report.

Per 15 U.S.C 1681e Whenever a consumer reporting agency prepares a consumer report it shall follow reasonable procedures to assure maximum possible accuracy of the information concerning the individual about whom the report relates.

According to 12 CFR Part 1022 ( Regulation V ) requires furnishers to : Furnish information concerning accounts or other relationships with a consumer that has integrity.

Furnish information about accounts or other relationships with a consumer that is accurate.

C - Conduct reasonable investigations of consumer disputes According to XXXX, in order to make a lawful report, you must follow the Metro 2 compliance standards. 

Also as stated in the XXXX Any Deviation From These Standards Jeopardizes The Integrity of The Data. This means that any mistakes in reporting claims can make the information less accurate and it affects the accuracy of any federally regulated reports.

Therefore, I am invoking my rights to challenge these inaccurate and non-compliant items. Neglecting my demand will only prove that you DO NOT care about my rights as a consumer. Its NOT FAIR for you to report information that isnt confirmed to be ethical and meets the standards of certified reporting. Again, I am challenging these claims and asking for proof of the proper reporting standards.

You are violating my rights! I have listed the concerns about your reporting in this document. It's not complete and does not meet my standards according to law, you must certify all aspects of required FCRA/ Metro 2 compliance which is done truthfully, correctly ( in a timely manner ), completely AND accurately as well - or else I would have to escalate these issues to the CFPB , FTC and my Attorney General.
Company public response: Company has responded to the consumer and the CFPB and chooses not to provide a public response
